data.author: Kyle Cesare
data.message:
Fix various Python wheel generation issues (#1188)

* Pass CLANG_RESOURCE_DIR to CastXML build.

* Silence FindBoost CMake warning CMake>=3.30.

* Build macos/arm64 wheels natively on M1 runner.

* Fix Boost errors and ensure numpy<=2.0.

* Fix CastXML can't find OMPL headers.

* Various fixes for Python wheel generation

Co-authored-by: Zachary Kingston <zkingston@purdue.edu>

* Bump CastXML to v0.6.8.

* Bump to llvm@18 for MacOS.

* Use system clang to build wheels on MacOS.

* Don't hardcode clang++ path in setup.py.

---------

Co-authored-by: Zachary Kingston <zkingston@purdue.edu>

fix signedness compare (for -Werror build) (#1181)

Fixes clang warning

ompl/geometric/planners/xxl/src/XXL.cpp:356:26: error: comparison of integers of different signs: 'int' and 'size_type' (aka 'unsigned long') [-Werror,-Wsign-compare]

ompl/demos/multilevel/MultiLevelPlanningKinematicChain.cpp:68:22: error: comparison of integers of different signs: 'value_type' (aka 'int') and 'const unsigned int' [-Werror,-Wsign-compare]

data.author: v4hn
data.message:
ensure that `webbrowser` pkg will not use terminal browser

for register step. If DISPLAY is not set, usually the command
would invoke a browser like `lynx`, `elinks`, etc.
However, that does not work because (1) the command output is quiet,
(2) cmake controls the shell, and (3) the browser does not quit without
user input anymore blocking the build. With the overridden TERM variable
the process will simply fail and the build goes on.

data.author: v4hn
data.message:
repair library install destination

unpatched:

ws $ catkin build
[...]
ws $ ls src/ install/lib/ install/share/
src/:
ompl

install/lib/:
pkgconfig

install/share/:
ament_index  catkin_tools_prebuild  libompl.so  libompl.so.1.6.0  libompl.so.17  man  ompl

patched:

ws $ catkin build
[...]
ws $ ls src/ install/lib/ install/share/
src/:
ompl

install/lib/:
libompl.so  libompl.so.1.6.0  libompl.so.17  pkgconfig

install/share/:
ament_index  catkin_tools_prebuild  man  ompl

data.author: v4hn
data.message:
Correctly overload virtual function

Not a problem in the current code base, but gcc produces a warning (or
error with -Werror)

Here's the exact warning:

ompl/src/ompl/datastructures/GridN.h:185:14: error: ‘bool ompl::GridN<_T>::remove(BaseCell*) [with _T = ompl::control::KPIECE1::Cel
lData*; BaseCell = ompl::Grid<ompl::control::KPIECE1::CellData*>::Cell]’ was hidden [-Werror=overloaded-virtual=]
  185 |         bool remove(BaseCell *cell) override
      |              ^~~~~~

data.author: Gaël Écorchard
data.message:
More relevant return code (#1147)

* Return the adequate error code

Signed-off-by: Gaël Écorchard <gael@km-robotics.cz>

* Return more appropriate status code in AnytimePathShortening

The AnytimePathShortening planner now returns INVALID_START or
INVALID_GOAL if any planner returned such status. Not all planners are
able to return INVALID_START or INVALID_GOAL, so this status is returned
if at least one planner returned it. If no planner returned
INVALID_START or INVALID_GOAL, the status is EXACT_SOLUTION or UNKNOWN.

Signed-off-by: Gaël Écorchard <gael@km-robotics.cz>

* Render code more readable and consistent

Signed-off-by: Gaël Écorchard <gael@km-robotics.cz>

setting this property requires CMake >=3.11 so the minimum version is
bumped.

data.author: JaeyoungLim
data.message:
Use of Dubins Set Classification for faster distance computations in DubinsStateSpace (#1080)

This adds dubins set classification in the DubinsStateSpace in order to make the dubins path computation more efficient. 

The classifications scheme is based on Shkel, Andrei M., and Vladimir Lumelsky. "Classification of the Dubins set." Robotics and Autonomous Systems 34.4 (2001): 179-202.

Additional correction is required for the classification scheme, where work from Lim, Jaeyoung, et al. "Circling Back: Dubins set Classification Revisited." Workshop on Energy Efficient Aerial Robotic Systems, International Conference on Robotics and Automation 2023. 2023. has been used.

data.author: Sotiris Papatheodorou
data.message:
Use more conservative types in PLY files (#1015)

In PLY files it is more common and well supported to use a uchar for the
number of face vertices and an int for the vertex indices. These are
also the types used in the PLY format description. Certain software
(e.g. Meshlab) doesn't support using a uint for either type.

http://paulbourke.net/dataformats/ply/

data.author: Marlin Strub
data.message:
Implementation of Effort Informed Trees (EIT*) (#844)

* Remove a blacklisted edge from the cache

This saves a nearest neighbor lookup, because not the whole cache is invalidated, but only the
invalid edge is removed from it.

* Use std::copy_if instead of a raw loop when caching neighbors

* Use van der Corput sequences to do sparse collision checking on reverse search

* Fix removing blacklisted states from cache

* Use the right destructor in AI-BIT*

* Fix assertions when forward iterating

These assertions don't necessarily hold true anymore since the forward queue is not cleared whenever
a collision is detected.

* Merge branch 'planner/ai-bitstar' into ai-bitstar/feature/edge-queue-update

* Specialize the queue for reverse and forward searches

* Reimplement outgoing edge queue lookups for efficient updating

* Reimplement outgoing edge queue lookups for efficient updating

* Merge branch 'ai-bitstar/fix/reimplementation-of-edge-queue-lookup' into planner/ai-bitstar

* Declare specializations of EdgeQueue template before first use

* Fix processing of invalid edge in reverse search

* Double the number of samples per batch whenever adding a new batch

* Update the children upon changing the cost-to-come

* Change from exception to bool return values when unable to update edge

Using exceptions in this case makes a surprisingly large difference in terms of performance (at
least for the wall gap problem).

* Update comments

* Keep batch size constant

* Add comments to the iterate() method of AI-BIT*

* Fix updateChildren() method in the vertex class

The children were never percolated up.

* Use the FMT* radius in AI-BIT*

* Merge branch 'fix/ai-bitstar-rewiring' into esp_ompl_tools

* Implement option to disable reverse collision detection in AI-BIT*

* Fix typos in method descriptions

* Implement backward search to fill effort estimates

* Initialize estimated and lowerbounding costs in states correctly

* Implement pruning in AI-BIT*

* Update comment in addState method of RandomGeometricGraph

* Avoid fetching the current cost on every sample

* Rename heuristic cost to estimated cost in edge struct

* Rename parent to source and child to target in the edge struct

This helps differentiate between edges in the RGG and edges in the search trees.

* Implement new queues for the forward and reverse search

* Remove cost field from edge class

* Clean up code by removing commented code

* Set the new suboptimality factor upon finding a new solution

* Reset the suboptimality factor when adding a new batch

Is this the correct behaviour?

* Exhaust the forward queue

* Fix setting the optimized flag when finding a new solution

* Cache the cost-to-go for all newly added states

* Store the problem definition in the graph

* Don't reset the lower bound cost to go when discovering a new vertex

* Set the start and goal state cost estimate/lower bound and effort estimate

* Cache sort keys in the forward queue

* Implement methods to do timings in AI-BIT*

* Store the cost of the current solution in AI-BIT*

* Initialize costs in vertices through the optimization objective

This is a safer option than initializing to the infinity value, as infinity does not always
correspond to infinite cost (e.g., min max clearance objective).

* Implement the main iteration method as a state machine

* Check for empty queue before entering the reverse search

* Make error more expressive when throwing because the reverse queue is empty

* Add field to vertex class that stores the cost at which the vertex was extended

* Declare const method "registerInvalidEdge" as const

* Decrease the reserved memory for the queue upon construction

* Remember the cost at which a vertex was expanded

* Implement initial draft of repairing reverse search

* Remove collision detection on reverse search

* Run clang-format on ReverseQueue.h

* Implement method to remove all outgoing edges of a vertex in the reverse queue

* Remove declaration of method that returns the out queue lookup

* Add more asserts to the vertex class

* Remove the dbg.h header and add the memory header

* Implement version of repairing backward search

* Make code to insert edge in queue more expressive and add comments

* Implement setter for repair and suboptimality factors

* Fix condition for expanding states in reverse search

* Change type of suboptimality factor in peek and pop methods of forward queue

* Fix the state id in the planner data

* Implement method to rebuild forward queue

* Fix repairing of reverse search

* Fix case where invalidated branch of reverse tree includes the reverse root

* Fix insertion of edges when reverse search must be restarted

* Implement method to check whether a vertex has children

* Declare local extendedCost variable closer to its first use

* Store the correct extended cost

A vertex is considered "extended" as soon as it gets its first child.

* Fix bug when repairing reverse search tree

Bug occured with the following config on the first run of AI-BIT*

{

    },

            "goal": [3.0, 3.0, 0.75, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0],
            "lowerBounds": [-3.8, -3.8, 0.0],

* Start cleaning up repairing of reverse search

* Stop truncating the forward search

* Encapsulate code to reparir reverse search tree in a method

* Implement option to disable repairing the reverse search tree

* Implement option to perform collision detection on reverse search

* Ensure the CD resolution on the reverse search is less than forward

* Implement remove method for ForwardQueue class

* Remove invalidated edges when rebuilding the queue

* Remove deprecated method to rebuild the forward queue

* Catch situation where repairing the reverse tree invalidates all edges in forward queue

* Clear the forward queue if no edge in it can improve current solution

* Replace the throw when popping an empty queue by an assert

* Fix the condition that ensures that only edges to the existing tree are inserted

* Rename Effort AI-BIT* to AEIT*

* Rename AEIT* to EIT*

* Encapsulate code that improves approximation in its own method

* Run clang-format on EITstar.cpp

* Fix the computation of the full-path heuristic in the forward search

* Make sure edges are not inserted multiple times

* Fix popping the lower-bounding edge from the forward queue

* Implement just-in-time reverse search

* Fix termination criteria for just-in-time reverse search

* Use full-path heuristic ordering in reverse search

* Fix condition for when to start reverse search

* Change hardcoded AEIT*'s in error strings to EIT*

* Clear both queues before improving the approximation

* Restructure control flow in couldBeValid method

* Fix condition in removeEdge method of the EIT*'s ForwardQueue

* Fix the lower bounding cost to come for the starts

* Reset the detection interpolation values when improving approximation in EIT*

* Add a comment in the clear method of the ForwardQueue of EIT*

* Improve the sparse collision detection algorithm in EIT*

Let's say I have an edge like this

         |--------------------------------------------------------------------|

Before this commit, the collision checking resolution was increased like this:

Level 0: |--------------------------------------------------------------------|
Level 1: |---------------------------------x----------------------------------|
Level 2: |----------------------x---------------------x-----------------------|
Level 3: |---------------x-----------------x-----------------x----------------|
Level 4: |------------x-------------x-------------x-------------x-------------|
Level 5: |---------x-----------x-----------x-----------x------------x---------|

But this means that by the time I get to, say, level 5, the distribution of checks looks like this:

Level 5: |---------x--x--x-----xx---x-----3x------x---xx-----x--x---x---------|

This is not exactly uniform. Instead the collision checking resolution is now like this:

Level 0: |--------------------------------------------------------------------|
Level 1: |---------------------------------x----------------------------------|
Level 2: |---------------x-----------------------------------x----------------|
Level 3: |-------x----------------x-----------------x-----------------x-------|

This means that already at level 3 we have the following distribution of checks:

Level 3: |-------x-------x--------x--------x--------x--------x--------x-------|

Compared to level 3 before, with only 1 check more.

Level 3: |---------------x------x---------2x----------x------x----------------|

One drawback of this approach is that some edges might not have been checked at previous levels, and
therefore the will not contain all checks. But since every level has a well distributed set of
checks on its own, I don't think this is a big deal. But it means that we can never whitelist an
edge if it passes a certain level, because we don't keep track of whether the edge also passed all
levels below.

* Make the initial number of sparse collision checks a parameter

* Support adding start and goal states while EIT* is solveing a problem

* Update include guards in EIT*

* Add const keyword to const variable

* Refactor EIT*

* Estimate admissible cost, cost, and effort in reverse search

* Implement pruning in EIT*

* Implement getter for whether reverse collision detection is enabled

* Fix updating cost of children

The edgeCost_ variable stores the cost of the incoming edge.

* Pass solution cost as const ref instead of shared ptr

* Fix inserting edges from jit cache

* Improve const correctness in EIT*

And other minor improvements

* Implement k-nearest version of EIT*

* Ensure EIT* is in a valid phase

Previous code did not change phase when the last edge in the forward queue was a freebie.

* Implement function that updates that JIT search edge cache

* Clean up logic when reverse search can be suspended

isAnyForwardRootInReverseTree() must be true if !doesImproveReversePath(edge) is true.

* Support accidentally sampling goals in EIT*

* Check the termination condition when drawing batches of samples

EIT* should try to respect the timeout condition. If it's expensive to sample states or unlikely to
sample valid states, this requires checking the termination condition when sampling batches of
states.

* Rename batch size parameter

* Implement getter for radius factor

* Implement EIT*-level getter and setter for max num goals

* Add parameters and progress properties to EIT*

* Support approximate solutions in EIT*

* Ensure informed samples aren't counted multiple times

Also check for condition when zero samples are to be added.

* Make resetting the suboptimality factor optional in EIT*

* Include parents and children in search trees as neighbors in EIT*

* Change lexicographical key of reverse search to consider effort

This helps tremendously when the admissible heuristic is the trivial zero heuristic.

* Fix case where forward edges can't be inserted and queue isn't empty

How did I miss this?

* Set suboptimality factor to 1 when solution is found

* Fix update of an edge in EIT*'s reverse queue

* Rename searchTag to reverseSearchTag to clarify which search it tags

* Fix const correctness in EIT*'s reverse search update method

* Gather using namespace declarations

* Make constructor explicit

* Rename forward and reverse search iterations

Match AIT*'s new implementation

* Implement checks whether to continue reverse and forward searches

* Refactor EIT*

* Decrease initial suboptimality factor and remove option to reset it

Infinity is a bad idea for the initial suboptimality factor as that will make
all edges in the queue look equally promising. The maximum double is also a bad
idea, as the suboptimality factor is multiplied with the cost-to-go and if that
cost is greater than 1, then it will result in infinity and we have the same
problem as before.

* Fix reverse queue

* Reinitialize the forward queue upon approximation change

* Squash this with "fix the reverse queue"

* Fix reverse search continuation condition

* Make sure the goals always have zero cost/effort-to-come

* Clear the forward queue lookup when clearing the forward queue

* Set the cost to come of the start state to identity

* Run clang format on Vertex.cpp

* Return empty edge when next edge is requested but queue is empty

* Use status codes instead of exceptions to signal setup failures

* Simplify peek method in the forward queue

* Fix rebuild method in forward queue

* Use auto for lambda arguments to make code less verbose

* Fix collision detection in reverse search

This fixes a bug in the sparse collision detection of the reverse search of
EIT*. Prior to this commit, the code implicitly assumed that all edges in the
graph had already been checked at the resolution of the last reverse search,
even though only the edges that were processed by the reverse search have
actually been checked. This commit adds a lookup to each state that caches the
collision detection resolution at which incoming edges were checked and skips
those checks when either checking the edge sparsely with higher resolution in
the reverse search and when checking the edge at full resolution in the forward
search.

* Populate the queues when setting up the planner

This makes more sense then checking whether it is the first iteration every
time solve is called.

* Stop reverse search when all targets in forward queue are closed

* Initialize the suboptimality factor to infinity

* Add additional stopping condition for reverse search

If the best edge in the forward queue is closed and there is no solution yet,
we can go. The forward tree will be repaired when the suboptimality factor decreases.

* Handle multiplication of infinite values specially

A single infinite value is fine but two infinite values result in NaNs.

* Compute the valid segment count in the forward direction

* Ensure effort estimate doesn't overflow in forward queue

* Fix assertion for closed target vertices in the forward search

If we suspended the reverse search because we don't care about solution costs
and the best state is connected to the reverse tree, then the associated vertex
does not have to be closed.

* Enhance legibility of reverse search suspension condition

* Fix clearing reverse queue lookup when clearing reverse queue

* Ensure that EIT* is setup before solving

* Implement clear and clear query for EIT*

* Implement tests for EIT*

* Fix signature for ensureSetup of EIT*

* Fix names of function calls

* Encapsulate condition for continuing solving problem in method

* Implement method that returns the current path to a state

* Add approximate solutions to problem definition

* Reverse sort order of edge vector in forward queue

Sorting from high to low is better because as soon as the suboptimality factor
becomes 1 we always get the edge with the lowest value and removing the last
element of a vector is much cheaper than removing the first.

* Fix pruning condition

We must not prune states that have a potential solution cost equal to the
current solution because if the current solution is optimal and we have a
perfect cost heuristic (e.g., straight-line between start and goal when
optimizing path length), then the goal and start will be pruned.

* Extend key of reverse queue with cost to target

If two edges in the reverse queue have equal total potential solution cost,
then we should tiebreak first on the cost to the target of the edge to save a
rewiring later. This almost never happens though because it's highly unlikely
that two edges have equal total potential solution cost unless the cost
heuristic is zero in which case they will also have equal cost to the target of
the edge and we're tiebreaking on the effort anyway.

* Fix comments

* Fix clear method

* Inform user when new solutions are found

* Rearrange code for collision detection to return early when possible

* Fix cached collision detection resolution

* Fix method to initialize state

* Fix clear method 2

* Activate PRM* radius

* Activate planner tests

* Call base clear query in EIT* clear query method

* Move EIT* to informedtrees folder

* Fix the queue-insertion for collision checks

- the 'else if' was introduced somewhere accidentally, which leads to
only inserting the first element, and only checking one half of each
segment, instead of the full one

* Clang-format all EIT* files

* Polish documentation of EIT*

* Update associated publication list of AIT*

* Add EIT* to the geometric pybindings headers

* Add short explanation and associated publication to EIT* class

* Fix memory leak caused by shared_ptr loops in EIT*

* Remove expired states from neighbor caches

* Adapt effort estimation to multi-q

- Now takes prev. validated edges into account
- Takes previously checked points into account

* Remove call to BasePlanner::clearQuery

This ends up calling clear(), which is not what we want.
Additionally, reset the suboptimality-parameter to inf.

* Change edges to 'whitelisted edges' in getPlannerData

* Re-initialize states if new starts/goals are added / old ones are
removed

* Adjust effort computation to take previously checked edges into account

* Switch to unordered_map for the forward queue, cache results

* Add timing capabilities for forward queue

* Enable keeping whitelisted edges in the neighbourhood-structure

* Avoid adding edges that have the parent of the current edge as target

* Add buffering of samples

* Update minEffortToCome computation

* Enable ordering the reverse queue on effort

* Distinguish between inadmissible/admissible effort

* Lots of changes, lost track of all of them

* Add small fix for circular dependencies

* Final start/goal pruning threshold

* Start/goal pruning cleanup

* Make code compile

* Add start/goal pruning again

* Add goal space enum back

* Add EIRM* specialization of EIT*

* Enable single-query mode again

* Multiquery RandomGeometricGraph

* Only add initial approximation in case we are using EIRM

* Remove lots of debugging comments

* Debugging counters removed

* More multiquery specific things

* Remove deprecated (commented) code

* Move pair-hasher to eitstar namespace

* Rename effort-threshold setter/getter

* Properly add first batch of samples for mq

* Documentation, lots of consts

* Clang format

* Revert "Add goal space enum back"

This reverts commit 5da659fe0326f575b2daef70faaa7f919d39901e.

* Fix double semicolon

* Add assert

* Lower bound Effort should be distinguished between sq/mq

* Change multiquery default of EIT*, move settings

* Fix rebase-issues

* Add description and links to EIRM*

* Small change to description

* Add EIRM* to 2d_circle_optimize test and optimal planning demo

* Add isEmpty functions for forward and reverse queue.

* Fix sanity check assert for number of performed collision checks

The full segment count should be greater or equal, because we never want to
check more than the full segment count.

* Consider reverse search vertices without potential children closed

Prior to this change: If a vertex cannot have any children, because it is not
close enough to any state except its parent, then it will never be considered
closed because vertices are considered closed when their first outgoing edge is
processed.

With this change: Vertices without any potential children are considered closed
when they are encountered. From an ordering perspective, this is equivalent to
the vertex having a potential child that is infinitely close to it, which EIT*
can handle.

I think this is conceptually correct and it satisfies the assert that checks
that all processed edges in the forward queue have target states that are
closed in the reverse search.

data.author: Wolfgang Hönig
data.message:
SST: Add support for IntermediateSolutionCallback of problem definition (#854)

SST currently just prints an information when a new solution is found.
This change calls the (optional) callback that a user can set to get
informed about new solutions, similar to BIT*, RRT* etc.

Co-authored-by: Wolfgang Hoenig <whoenig@caltech.edu>

data.author: Wolfgang Hönig
data.message:
Optimization Objectives: Add support for control-space planners (#853)

Optimization Objectives: Add support for control-space planners

OptimizationObjective was designed for geometric planning and cannot
associate costs with ompl::control::Control. This addresses this short-
coming in the following way:

* New controlCost(control, steps) function (defaults to identityCost)
* New ControlDurationObjective, which minimizes the total time needed
* Support for controlCost() in the control-space version of SST

Other typical control-space costs include control-integral costs, but
are application-specific and can be now defined by the user by creating
a derived class inheriting from OptimizationObjective().

Co-authored-by: Wolfgang Hoenig <whoenig@caltech.edu>

data.author: Marlin Strub
data.message:
Set the sampled cost to identity when adding a new batch in BIT* (#812)

Here's how I understand what the problem was: If sampling from a compound state
space with RealVectorStateSpaces as components, then direct informed sampling
is used for these components. To support just-in-time sampling, BIT* samples
shells of the informed set in these components. These shells are defined by a
minimum and maximum cost. The issue with initializing sampledCost_ as the
minimum possible cost to solve the problem is that some of that cost might come
from non-RealVectorStateSpace components of the compound state space, e.g., the
angular component in SE(2). If this is the case, then the center of the
informed set in the RealVectorStateSpace components is never sampled.

We could initialize sampledCost_ to the smallest minimum possible cost of each
RealVectorStateSpace component of the compound space, but that is nontrivial to
figure out and also not necessary. Instead we can just initialize sampledCost_
to identity, which ensures that the center of all informed sets in all
RealVectorStateSpaces is sampled.

data.author: Marlin Strub
data.message:
Refactor AIT* (#813)

* Implement method to insert goal vertices in reverse queue

* Fix typo in comment

* Implement methods to compare keys of edges and vertices

* Improve const correctness when inserting edges in forward queue

* Only update edges in the forward queue if their key has improved

* Implement method to insert multiple edges in forward queue

* Implement check to continue reverse search

* Refactor the update of the reverse search vertex

* Implement method to update all reverse search neighbors of a vertex

* Implement methods to clear queues

* Remove edge cache

* Keep track of all edges in the forward queue that must be resorted

* Simplify iteration method

* Expand the start states into the forward queue on first iteration

* Implement new reverse suspension condition

* Make constructor explicit

* Implement methods to reset the (expanded) cost to come from goal

* Remove unnecessary operations when invalid edge is found

* Remove methods to un/register expansions in reverse search

They're not necessary.

* Remove unused member variable expandedReverseSearchId_

* Assert that the cost to come from goal is zero when updating a goal

* Remove check of the reverse parent for best cost

This check is redundant as the bestParent and bestCost variables are
initialized with the values of the reverse parent.

* Update vertex no matter whether it is orphaned if it is inconsistent

* Fix method to invalidate cost to come in reverse branch

Reset both the current cost to come from goal and the expanded cost to come
from goal and remove the branch from the tree as it is no longer valid. Also
update the affected edges in the forward queue.

* Drop unnecessary aitstar:: namespace specifier

* Put queue types in its own header file

* Implement single method to update exact and approximate solutions

* Remove unnecessary registrations of popped vertices in forward queue

* Run clang-format on AITstar.cpp

* Clean up implementation of forward search iteration

* Clean up implementation of invalidating a reverse search branch

* Add missing include and forward declare edge and vertex class

* Refactor AIT*'s solve method

Includes a function to call another function on a branch of the forward search
tree.

* Report number of goal and start states

* Implement option to limit the number of sampled goals in AIT*

* Fix reverse search stopping condition in AIT*

* Fix parameter type for set_max_num_goals

* Try to get a start state if the problem is not setup properly

* Remove unused member variables from AIT*

* Prioritize inconsistent vertices with edges in the forward queue

When two vertices have equal costs, then prioritize the vertex that has
incoming edges in the forward queue.

* Stop reverse search if all targets in forward queue are consistent

Consistent targets means admissible heuristics.

* Set setup_ flag to false in AITstar::clear()

* Ensure that the planner is setup each time solve is called

* Run clang format on AIT* and homogenize copyright notice

data.message:
Fix/aitstar miscellaneous (#763)

* Fix neighbor cache in AIT*

Switch to storing cached neighbors in weak pointers, as shared pointers can result in memory leaks.

* Fix AIT*'s caching of whitelisted children

The cache sometimes held weak pointers to vertices that were once whitelisted as children but have
since been pruned. This commit fixes that by checking whether the vertex is still valid and removing
it from the cache if not.

* Add AIT* to optimal planning demo

Add 'AITstar' as an option for the optimal planning demo.

* Check termination condition between each successful sample

If sampling valid states is expensive, AIT* does not respect the timeout conditions otherwise.

Fix AIT*'s clear method (#723)

Clear() should reset the planner to the state it had before it started solving the problem, not the
state it had before receiving the problem definition. Since the k-nearest RGG constant only depends
on the state space dimension (which is part of the problem definition), it should not get reset when
clear is called.

data.author: Marlin Strub
data.message:
Implementation of Adaptively Informed Trees (AIT*) (#719)

* Implement first draft of TBD*

* Insert a vertex's current children when expanding it

* Fix setting cost to come from goal

* Allocate the queue and the graph on the stack instead of the heap

* Update queues for cleaner code

* Insert a vertex's childs in the backward queue

* Update vertex class and iteration structure

* Encapsulate the logic of updating a solution into its own method

* Whitelist edges that are known to not be in collision

* Implement LPA* on backward search

* Reset backward queue pointer after removing element from queue

* Make repairing the backward search optional

* Ensure that the forward search is started in all cases

Forward search never started if initial batch did not contain solution

* Ensure nearest neighbor cache is used

* Implement nontrivial heuristic in backward search

* Return const references when returning start and goal vertices

* Initialize the start vertices with proper identity costs

* Update comments

* Reserve size of vector before placing elements into it

* Make backward search termination criterion more general

* Allow setting batch size as an option

* Do not clear backward queue too often and use extended graph

* Remove invalidated vertices from the open queue

* Add samples if no start is connected to any goal through the backward tree

* Remove debug prints

* Allow more settings for TBDstar

Rewire factor and stopping on finding initial solution

* If any of the start states are underconsistent, the LPA* must continue

At least according to the latest paper, page 54:

@article{aine2016,
  title =        {Truncated Incremental Search},
  author =       {S. Aine and M. Likhachev},
  journal =      {Artificial Intelligence},
  volume =       234,
  pages =        {49--77},
  year =         2016,
  publisher =    {Elsevier}
}

* LPA* updates the g values with the v values of the parent states

Compare with the latest publication, page 54:

@article{aine2016,
  title =        {Truncated Incremental Search},
  author =       {S. Aine and M. Likhachev},
  journal =      {Artificial Intelligence},
  volume =       234,
  pages =        {49--77},
  year =         2016,
  publisher =    {Elsevier}
}

* Implement the sort key of LPA* correctly

* Activate FMT* radius in TBD*

* Rename TBD* to AIT*

* Remove unused private member

* Use ompl::base::Cost instead of doubles in queue key comparisons

* Fix name of variable in assert statement

* Fix just-in-time backward search in AIT*

* Resample raw states when sampled states are invalid

This avoids allocating too many vertices and makes sure that the vertex ids are contiguous.

* Fix behaviour in case of reverse search tree splitting into multiple components

* Implement pruning in AIT*

* Do not check a vertex' backward children as possible new parents

The children should never be the new parent of a vertex.

* Set the expanded cost of an invalidated vertex to infinity

* Use the expanded cost in the update vertex method of AIT* consistently

* Insert potential new best parents into backward queue after invalidating a branch

* Use the current parent as initial best cost when looking for updates

* Update invalidated vertices and insert into queue if they become part of the tree

* Remove outgoing edges of invalidated vertices from the forward queue

To do this efficiently, AIT*'s vertices now have to keep track of outgoing edges in the forward
queue. Since incoming edges to invalidated vertices must also be removed, they also keep track of
incoming edges in the forward queue.

* Support adding start and goal states while AIT* is solving a problem

* Fix error that pops goal instead of start vertices when reviving starts

* Reactivate the RRT* radius in AIT*

* Clear forward queue lookups of edges in queue before clearing queue

* Ensure registration of adding children to vertices is done correctly

Registering the expansion was a bit of a misnomer. Expanding means getting a vertice's neighbors,
and that's actually not what's relevant here. We need to make sure that a vertices cost-to-come
doesn't change once it has a child added to it, as this would invalidate the cost-to-come of the children.

* Add comments and clean run clang-format on all files

* Implement tracking approximate solutions and clearing AIT*

* Add AIT* to the 2dcircles_optimize unit test

* Add AIT* to the markdown documentation

* Add specs, and settings to AIT* and declare parameters

* Remove the option to stop on inition solution

This is redundant as it can be achieved by using OptimizationObjective::setCostThreshold to let the
objective know that any solution with lower than infinite cost is acceptable (assuming the cost is minimized).

* Clean up how AIT* checks for approximate solutions

* Add the number of iterations to the progress properties of AIT*

* Remove unrelated readme from AIT*'s folder

* Rename backward search to reverse search in AIT*

This ensures AIT*'s implementation uses the same name for the search from the goal to the start
as AIT*'s publication.

* Clarify documentation of AIT*

* Make check for resolution-optimal cost-to-come in AIT* more strict

While the previous condition was not wrong, this is more strict.

* Consider vertices processed when they've been popped from the queue

This ensure that the vertices are optimally connected in the reverse search tree.

* Use consistent include guards and update comments in AIT*

* Remove forward and reverse search Ids from AIT*

These ids were used in the implicit graph and the vertex class, but since we now repair the reverse
tree instead of restarting from scratch (like we did in the very beginning) they are always in sync
with the batch id anyway and so it doesn't make sense to keep them around.

* Use typenames for the forward and reverse queue elements

This makes the types of the lookups more readable.

* Allocate batch id and solution cost on the stack instead of the heap

Passing the solution cost to the graph by const reference there's no way it's not in the
same or an encompassing scope. Same argument for the batch id and the vertices.

* Allocate AIT*'s queues on the stack

* Rename 'bitstar' folder to 'informedtrees' and add aitstar to it

data.author: Marlin Strub
data.message:
Implementation of Advanced BIT* (ABIT*) (#715)

* Fix condition under which goals are pruned in BIT*

The method vertexPruneCondition tests g_t(v) + h^(v) > g_t(x_g).
The method samplePruneCondition tests g^(v) + h^(v) > g_t(x_g).

Goals should only be pruned if they are not in the informed set, which is what samplePruneCondition tests.

* Rename member variables that hold samples and vertices

* Rename member variable that hold the number of new samples in current batch

* Rename space information and problem definition variables

* Rename method to enqueue edges to samples

* Rename method to enqueue edges to vertices

* Rename method that lexicographically compares two sort keys

* Rename methods that return sort keys

* Merge branch 'bitstar_regression' into refactor/bitstar_search_queue

* Rename vertex queue token memeber variable

* Remove argument to update child costs as it is always called with true

* Rename methods and variables around the edge queue lookups

* Overload method since we're already passing in what we want out

* Rename variables that store solution costs and methods that register them

* Rename parent pointer variable and getter method

* Rename const state getter to be an overload

* Rename distance method

* Rename methods that check whether edge/vertex can possibly improve
current solution

* Rename methods that check whether vertex/sample/edge can be pruned

* Rename and clean up methods that handle superfluous edges in queue

* Rename method that resorts or clears the search queue

* Rename method that expands a vertex

What else would it expand?

* Update debug code to new names

Lesson: Use rtags renaming capability with debug flag turned on

* Change edge blacklist mechanism

Instead of the indirect check whether a vertex was expanded towards
old/new samples and other vertices, this commit implements an edge
blacklist that directly saves the ids of children which are not
suitable as targets for outgoing edges.

* Stop keeping track of distances when blacklisting children

Profiling the code reveals that looking up children in the blacklist
is an insignificant fraction (0.02%) of the computational
cost. Also, the topology of the search space would have to be really
weird for the list to grow indefinitely.

* Remove redundant logic for edge collision check chaching

Keeping track of old and new samples and whether a vertex has been
expanded to samples and/or to vertices or not is ultimately just a way
to avoid collision checking the same edges multiple
times. Blacklisting edges achieves the same result.

* Use consistent variable names

* Implement edge whitelist

Profiling reveals that collision checking for edges is by far the most
expensive part of the algorithm. Whitelisting edges, i.e., caching
results of collision checks that determined that there was no
collision, alleviates some of that computational cost.

* Use consistent variable names

* Remove deprecated method

* Use consistent names for methods

* Separate logic to add sample to vertices and remove it from samples

In my opinion, this clarifies the function at the callsite. I don't
like argument flags at all.

* Disentangle logic to insert a vertex

Breaking up intertwined methods helps composability and is a first
step towards ABIT*.

* Disentangle logic to insert vertex into queue and add it into set of vertices

* Use consistent variable and method names

* Disentangle vertex remove helper method

* Use more expressive method name for vertex remove helper

* Disentangle logic to remove vertex from set and from queue

* Implement method to recycle sample

* Update comments to reflect new method functionality

* Initial commit for direct expansion of vertices

* Merge branch 'set_planner_seeds' into refactor/bitstar-search-queue

* Don't mark vertices unsorted

* Check if expanding existing edge, reset queue after adding samples

* Delete regression class

* Enable pruning vertices in the graph class

This is costlier than pruning through the vertex queue, which is
probably why the pruning of the vertices was implemented in the
queue. Preliminary results suggest, however, that not having to
maintain the vertex queue seems to improve overall performance.

* Use consistent method names

* Remove getters related to the vertex queue

* Remove functionality connected to vertex queue

* Use consistent method names

* Move the prune conditions to the graph

Pruning is done through the graph now, there's no reason these
conditions should live in the search queue.

* Add a vertex' outgoing edges to its currents children

This is crucial, how could I forget?

* Update method descriptions and use consistent naming

The spring-clean-commit, dotting the Is and crossing the Ts.

* Keep naming consistent

* Keep naming and comment style consistent

Second part of the spring clean, adding some missing punctuation and
renaming some variables and methods.

* Merge method to combine multiple costs

Variadic templates ftw

* Inflate cost-to-go and implement crude inflation policy

* Make vertices aware of the current search & approximation ids

Allowing vertices read access to the memory where the current search and
approximation ids are stored allows for better encapsulation. It
replaces the copy of an int with a dereference operation, but that's a
price I'm willing to pay given the cleaner implementation.

* Implement repairing search upon decrease of inflation factor

To achieve proper ARA* like behaviour, we need to keep track of the
set of inconsistent vertices. That's because upon researching the same
approximation with a new inflation factor, we don't have to begin from
the start vertex. We only have to consider the edges that are still
open, and the ones that are outgoing of inconsistent vertices.

* Move prune method out of new batch method

The two methods conceptually don't have anything to do with each
other. Let's separate them to make that clear.

* Rebuild the edge queue instead of updating all edges individually

This must be at least as efficient, right?

* Fix free edge expansion check

Kinda embarrassing. How was this so subtle and didn't cause double the trouble?

* Fix method to pop front edge

* Remove incoming edges from queue when pruning a sample

* Add more sanity checks when debug flag is defined

* Fix method to prune vertices

* Clear the search queue upon restarting with a new batch

* Update comments

* Ensure testing the straight paths from starts to goals

* Reset the approximation id in reset method

* Fix only insertion of outgoing edges of start vertices

* Clear lookups and black-/whitelists of start and goal vertices on reset

* Report the correct number of pruned and disconnected vertices

* Rename pruning setting

* Make copy of vertices and samples publicly available

* Rename method to get number of vertices and samples

* Rename method to more accurately reflect what it does

* Allow for more general inflation factor policies

* Save sample indices with planner data

* Implement truncation

* Remove redundant check for unit inflation

* Set inflation and truncation factor policies

* Allow setting inflation and truncation factor policy parameters

* Add a vector of new samples instead of each sample one by one

* Fix typo

* Update outgoing edges in the queue upon vertex cost change

* Count number of samples in informed set when computing RGG radius

* Fix computation of samples that can be pruned in BIT*

* Fix pruning of goal states

* Fix warnings for unused variables

* Allow setting the average number of failed attempts at sampling in BIT*

* Update the pruning criterion

Profiling reveals that pruning is very expensive, mainly because the
nearest neighbour structure of the samples has to be updated. On the
other hand, nearest neighbour lookup gets more expensive the bigger
the structure, so it's a tradeoff. Pruning on every cost update seems
insensible, but so does never pruning at all. The criteria to prune
should depend on how many vertices/samples there are and how many of
them could be pruned, as the decrease in cost associated with nearest
neighbour lookup for fewer samples must justify the cost of pruning.
It turns out that counting is affordable, so we don't need to use any
proxy here.

* Run clang-format on BIT* base class and implicit graph

* Add missing member variable for average number of sampling attempts

* Remove unused methods from BIT*

* Initialize the best cost to be infinity according to the optimization objective

Some optimization objectives define infiniteCost as 0 (e.g., max-min-clearance), so we should
use this to initialize the best cost.

* Correctly set whether a solution is optimized through the intended interface

* Keep pruned states alive if they are returned in plannerdata

* Replace the dual nearest neighbor structure with a single structure

* Implement option to disable cascading of rewirings

* Create a ABIT* as a separate class

Turn the new BIT* implementation into ABIT* by setting the right options.

* Remove option to set local seed used for debugging

* Remove inconsistent children of pruned vertices from the inconsistent set

* Add new samples after pruning

The main reason is that the newBatch method updates the nearest neighbor terms for the new RGG. This
should be done after pruning, because the measure of the informed set is updated in the prune function.

* Update authorlist for BIT*

* Include RGG connectivity model in ABIT*'s default names

This makes it consistent with BIT*. I remember being surprised once by the renaming in BIT* so
let's warn the user if that happens. (A user could name an r-disc version of BIT* "kBITstar" and I
don't think it's the best idea to silently rename it to "BITstar").

* Clarify parameter names for inflation and truncation update policies

This commit also adds additional documentation that explains the inflation and truncation update
policies to ABIT*'s class description.

* Fix const correctness in variadic implementation of combineCosts

* Update getter and setter names in ABIT*

* Add ABIT* to the markdown planner documentation

* Be consistent in naming when declaring ABIT* parameters

* Check for goal when getting next goal via planner input states

Calling PlannerInputStates::nextGoal when the problem definition does not have a goal yet resulted in
a segfault. This commit makes sure nextGoal returns a nullptr when there is no goal instead of segfaulting.

* Add BIT* and ABIT* to planner unit test

* Link to the ICRA presentation video in the ABIT* description

And use a shorter link for the submission video.

* Clear inconsistent vertices when resetting the search queue in ABIT*

data.author: Mark Moll
data.message: fix cmake warnings. minor doc fixes

data.author: Mark Moll
data.message:
New & improved version of AnytimePathShortening. (#690)

* New & improved version of AnytimePathShortening.

The main improvement is that threads no longer need to be synchronized.
Each thread independently produces as many solutions as possible. The
main thread applies path hybridization and simplification.

* bug fixes and improvements to AnytimePathShortening, small API change in
PathHybridization

- PathHybridation now uses PathGeometric everywhere rather than the base
  class Path to avoid unnecessary casting and enforce correct usage
- Path simplification and hybridization is cost-aware, so no need for
  warning about optimization objectives different form path length.
- Only run path hybridization when there's a change in the top paths
  considered for hybridization.
- Fix bug in returning correct planner status.
- Use mutex for changing bestCost_
- clang-format


* remove done_ member, use ptc.terminate() instead

data.author: Dmitry Rozhkov
data.message:
Add option to skip setting RPATH

OMPL installs to /usr/lib by default and some projects integrating
OMPL trigger a QA check suggesting that the set RPATH is useless.
For example Yocto gives this warning:

    QA Issue: ompl: /work/corei7-64-refkit-linux/ompl/1.1.0-r0/packages-split/ompl/usr/lib/libompl.so.1.1.0 contains probably-redundant RPATH /usr/lib [useless-rpaths]

Add the option OMPL_SKIP_RPATH that helps to skip setting RPATH
for the library. By default the option is OFF.

data.author: Dmitry Rozhkov
data.message:
address gcc6 build error

With gcc6, compiling fails with `stdlib.h: No such file or directory`,
as including '-isystem /usr/include' breaks with gcc6, cf.,
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=70129.

This commit addresses this issue for this package in almost the same way
it was addressed in various other ROS packages. A list of related
commits and pull requests is at:

    https://github.com/ros/rosdistro/issues/12783

Particularly when searching for the Boost library CMake sets
Boost_INCLUDE_DIRS to @SYSROOT@/usr/include which should be
avoided in the `-isystem` option of gcc.

BIT* updates and a new associated algorithm, SORRT*

data.author: Jonathan Gammell
data.message: A cleaner refactoring of BIT* that highlights the conceptual idea of separting the anytime approximation of a continuous planning problem from the anytime search of the representation.

data.author: Jonathan Gammell
data.message:
Thesis version of Informed RRT*, SORRT*, and BIT*.
Includes some improvements to algorithms, as well as:
 - Cleaning up queue sorting with std::array and std::lexicographical_compare.
 - Creation of a cost/heuristic helper class that removes a bunch of function pointers.
 - Optional approximate solution support (disabled by default)

data.author: Mark Moll
data.message:
Require C++11. Replace a lot of Boost usage with equivalent things from the C++11 standard library. Eliminate any leftover gccxml-related code since it cannot parse C++11. Python bindings can only be generated with castxml. By switching boost::shared_ptr to std::shared_ptr we are losing some of the built-in smarts of Boost.Python. To get around this I have copied over the relevant bits of Boost.Python code and modified it to use std::shared_ptr.

Remaining issues:
- Interrupting a std::thread is not possible, so maybe bring back boost:thread for Benchmark class so that we can kill a stuck planner?
- Instead of boost::noncopyable, use the "= delete" C++11 feature to just delete the copy constructor?
- Check performance of Permutation class in GNATs.
- Fix python bindings (they *almost* work)

--HG--

- Bug fixes to both GNAT implementations:
	- Correctly process all nodes in NodeQueue in nearestKInternal method (termination condition was wrong and resulted in rare crashes when removing elements)
	- Correctly set size when adding vector of elements to non-empty GNAT.
	- Correct calculation of degree of child node when a node is split.
- Improve performance by changing default parameters for GNAT (tested with uniform random sampling in SE(3), YMMV).
- White space changes to conform to style guide.
- Add some documentation to permutation class.

Fixed obscure RRT* bug.
Bug only apparent when cost function can return negative costs, sometimes resulting in an invalid rewire operation that breaks the tree structure.
There was already a check in place for this, but it was insufficient. It only performed the check on the parent node. This fix performs the check on all ancestor nodes.

data.author: Mark Moll
data.message: Create consistent behavior across all planners that can optimize paths. Calls to the solve method of RRT*, PRM*, SPARS, SPARStwo, and LBTRRT will terminate when (1) the planner termination condition is true or (2) the optimization objective is satisfied. To make these planners terminate when *any* solution is found, just set the cost threshold for the optimization objective to, e.g., OptimizationObjective::infiniteCost(). The collisionChecks_ progress property was removed from RRT*, since it didn't accurately count the number of calls to the stateValidityChecker.

data.author: clarkaa10
data.message:
----------------------------------------------------
Changes in FMT.h:
----------------------------------------------------
Swapped the parameter 'obstacleCoverage_' for 'freeSpaceVolume_'. Ideally, we would like to use a variable called 'freeSpaceFraction_,' that denotes the fraction of the configuration space that is free of obstacles. If the state space class had a 'getVolume()' method, then we could implement this alternative FMT class variable and make the algorithm interface easier for the user.

Added a 'maxSampleAttempts_' class variable.

Added a 'lastGoalMotion_' class variable.

Changed the radiusMultiplier_ lower bound to 0 instead of 1.

Removed the class variable 'children' from the Motion class.

Minor stylistic changes.

----------------------------------------------------
Changes in FMT.cpp:
----------------------------------------------------
In the constructor -
Swapped the parameter 'obstacleCoverage_' for 'freeSpaceVolume_.'
Added the 'maxSampleAttempts_' variable.
Added the 'lastGoalMotion_' variable.
Updated the planner parameter suggested ranges.

In solve -
Set the variable lastGoalMotion_ at the end of solve().

In getPlannerData-
Handled start and goal states differently than other states.

In assureGoalIsSampled:
Utilized the nextGoal() function in a while loop, in place of the for loop that was previously implemented.

Minor stylistic changes.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
Implemented the .goalRegion functionality. An object with this name suffix will be automatically converted into a collision sensor and the goal will not be satisfied unless the corresponding rigid body is colliding with it. This allows the user to specify an arbitrarily shaped region that an object must touch in order to satisfy the goal.

Moved some of the goal setup code from builder.py to the Plan operator in ompl_addon.py.in. The changes performed automatically are thus saved to the .blend file so they don't have to be re-performed every time unless the user destroys them.

Included a new bgetest2.blend file illustrating the use of .goalRegion objects.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
Instead of simple .goal objects that require the bodies to have the given position and orientation within a hardcoded tolerance, now we use .goalLocRot and .goalRot objects with 'locTol' and 'rotTol' object properties to specify the goal criteria more carefully.
Ex: using a .goalLocRot object with a locTol of 3.0 and a rotTol of 1.0 indicates that the body must be within 3 units of the goal location, and the rotation is irrelevant for this goal criterion.
Eventually there will be a .goalRegion object type that is satisfied if the body intersects the region. This is intended to be used together with a .goalRot object to specify desired region and orientation.

Bounds configuration menu refuses to open if the control dimension is greater than 16. It's infeasible to handle more than that in one menu.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message: The MORSE robots now retain the name given by the user in Blender rather than being called robot_0, robot_1, etc. Allows for more clarity in the Bounds Configuration dialog.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
CMake now automatically configures ompl_addon.py to know where to find the other scripts, which are now properly installed. (The configured ompl_addon.py is located in build/scripts/morse.)
Bug fix: the Add Robot function in the OMPL menu cannot be run unless Blender is in Object Mode (the addon previously crashed when the user tried to add a robot in, e.g., Edit Mode.)

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
Improved the bounds configuration menu. It now supports up to 16 control inputs, allowing the user to set different bounds for each. The input fields are organized first by robot, then by service name (like set_speed). If the control dimension is fewer than 16, only the necessary input fields are shown.
Changed two of the scripts to determine where their directory is automatically.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message: Merged ompl/ompl into default

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message: The builder.py script now uses the wmctrl tool (http://linux.die.net/man/1/wmctrl) to 'shade' the planning window so that only its title bar is visible, thus hiding the plannig process from the user automatically. This, of course, requires wmctrl to be installed.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
Add a Bounds Configuration button the OMPL menu in Blender. This brings up a dialog allowing users to set bounds for
position, linear and angular velocity, and control inputs. There is also a check box for determining the position bounds
automatically. Values are saved to a __settings object in the *.blend file.

Notice: I changed the interface to my speed-hacked Blender. This commit can't plan or play since it doesn't include
those changes.

data.author: Caleb Voss
data.message:
Made tweaks to the timing and logic situation in communicator.py so Blender spends less time waiting on OMPL.
Physics now takes up ~80% of the time in Blender, up from ~40% before the tweaks.

Also, communicator.py sends all the bounds information (positional, linear, angular, and control) to environment.py
based on numbers it finds in a __settings object in the *.blend file. (See next commit.)

--HG--

data.author: Luis G. Torres
data.message:
Added a getCostValue() pure virtual method to OptimizationObjective which returns a double-valued representation of the given cost. This is used by the isCostLessThan() method to compare costs. Also, isCostLessThan() is no longer virtual, so that the base OptimizationObjective class can perform cost comparisons in a numerically robust way using a magic constant.

data.author: Luis G. Torres
data.message:
Fixed BallTreeRRTstar (as far as I can tell). Previous issues came from:

1) Goal-biased samples were getting rejected
2) When goal-biased samples were accepted, sometimes BallTreeRRTstar would add multiple goal samples with the EXACT SAME STATE to the tree, which meant some infinite-radius balls would never be trimmed and therefore all samples were rejected

data.author: Luis G. Torres
data.message:
Ripped out shared_ptr-based Cost mechanism and made it similar to how State* is handled. Big speed-up, and now RRT* using a generalized cost is very nearly as fast as with a double-valued cost. Only source of slowdown is in the casting of a general cost to a specific type of cost, now.

data.author: Luis G. Torres
data.message:
- Implemented a generalized notion of cost. Cost is no longer assumed to be just a double value, accrued by addition.
- Previous subclasses of OptimizationObjective now reside in the ompl::geometric namespace because they were devised with geometric paths in mind.
- Removed cost() method from Path (and its subclasses); OptimizationObjective should now be used to compute cost of a path (this made lots of the implementation FAR simpler).
- Removed OptimizationObjective from ompl/geometric/PlannerIncludes.h, since many planners are not making use of OptimizationObjective. This reduces compile times greatly.
- Adjusted RRTstar and PRM planners for change to cost mechanism. Also required changes to ompl/tools/multiplan/OptimizePlan
- For now, disabled use of getTerminalCost() because I literally have no idea what that method does.
- For now, disabled BallTreeRRTstar because I just don't want to re-implement it to work with asymmetric spaces and generalized costs right now.

STILL TODO:
- fix BallTreeRRTstar (and add it back to its CMakeLists.txt)
- make sure the formatting and documentation for my added stuff works
- change GeometricOptimizationObjective to something more meaningful (and maybe put definitions for PathLenghOO and StateCostOO in their own files)
- figure out what getTerminalCost() does and re-incorporate it
- there's redundancy in cost computation in the MotionValidator and StateValidityChecker classes; figure out why costs are computed there, and see if we can refactor.
- personal gripe: all the const WhateverPtr& stuff doesn't actually induce useful const-correctness to data that WhateverPtr points to. Might propose adding yet another typedef to OMPL_CLASS_FORWARD which creates a boost::shared_ptr<const T> called something like CWhateverPtr, or WhateverPtr_C that actually implies const-correctness.

--HG--

data.author: Mark Moll
data.message: Added generic way to export boost::function types to python. This eliminates lots of wrapper code. The python code now needs to explicitly `cast' a python function to the desired boost::function type. This new generic way only works with the preferred boost::function syntax (e.g., boost::function<int(double,int)> ) rather than the portable syntax we used so far (e.g., boost::function2<int,double,int> ). Let's hope this doesn't cause any problems with common compilers. The gccxml compiler generates broken code with the preferred boost::function syntax, so we need to fix up the code in a cmake post-processing script.

data.author: Ioan Sucan
data.message:
changed the concept of state validity checking resolution. Since computing distance between states is difficult, specifying such resolutions is a black art. To avoid this, we use the extents of the manifolds and define this notion differently: as a percentage of the maximum extent. For compound manifolds, this uses the max() operator instead of weighted sums.

--HG--
